HDG.FS.content: “reflection,” Latin re-flexere, turning-back upon itself (zurückzuwenden), towards the ego > in Descartes, ego, as cogitans, appears as cogitatum, object > in Kant’s language: “it must be possible for the I think to accompany all my representations” > transcendental apperception re: finite essence of man > Hegel absolutizes finite understanding, brings power of conjoining to absolute power: “what is finite w/ man becomes the infinite Absolute” > infinite as sublation of finite

HDG.FS.content: how does Platonic idea (eidos) correspond to what Greeks named presence, ousia, the most extreme excess? for Plato, to change, to alter oneself (sich ändern): abwesen (to absence)—idea as pure presence, never absencing, self-maintaining-making-present, presencing presence (anwesende Anwesenheit) as what’s there in excess, ontos on (Nietzsche had strong sense of this, Twilight of…)
